title: 150 Clear already committed files but included in .gitignore

Sometimes it happens that a file was being tracked by git, but in a later point in time was added to .gitignore, in order to stop tracking it. It’s a very common scenario to forget to clean up such files before its addition to .gitignore. In this case, the old file will still be hanging around in the repository.

inline_content.Text: Sometimes it happens that a file was being tracked by git, but in a later point in time was added to .gitignore, in order to stop tracking it. It’s a very common scenario to forget to clean up such files before its addition to .gitignore. In this case, the old file will still be hanging around in the repository.

title: To fix this problem, one could perform a “dry-run” removal of everything in the repository, followed by re-adding all the files back. As long as you don’t have pending changes and the
--cached
c
parameter is passed, this command is fairly safe to run:

inline_content.Text: To fix this problem, one could perform a “dry-run” removal of everything in the repository, followed by re-adding all the files back. As long as you don’t have pending changes and the
parameter is passed, this command is fairly safe to run:

title:
# Remove everything from the index (the files will stay in the file system) 
$ git rm -r --cached .

# Re-add everything (they'll be added in the current state, changes included)
$ git add .

# Commit, if anything changed. You should see only deletions
$ git commit -m 'Remove all files that are in the .gitignore'

# Update the remote
$ git push origin master

content_resolved.code:
# Remove everything from the index (the files will stay in the file system) 
$ git rm -r --cached .

# Re-add everything (they'll be added in the current state, changes included)
$ git add .

# Commit, if anything changed. You should see only deletions
$ git commit -m 'Remove all files that are in the .gitignore'

# Update the remote
$ git push origin master
